description: A classic and beloved Ugandan comfort food pairing creamy, smooth mashed green bananas (matooke) with a rich, savory, and flavorful liver stew.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: This dish is a staple in many Ugandan homes. The matooke is a carbohydrate cornerstone, while the liver is a prized and nutritious organ meat. It's a common, affordable, yet special meal that showcases the versatility of Uganda's national food.

ingredients.name: Onions
ingredients.notes: 1 chopped for stew, 1 sliced for steaming matooke

steps.instruction: Prepare the liver: Place the sliced liver in a bowl. Add lemon juice or vinegar and a pinch of salt. Rub it thoroughly and rinse under cold water. This removes any bitterness and cleans it. Set aside.
Peel the matooke. Use a knife to make a slit along the length of each finger and peel off the skin. Keep the peeled matooke in a bowl of water to prevent discoloration.

Steam the matooke: Line a large pot with banana leaves (if using). Place the peeled matooke inside. Add a sliced onion on top for flavor. Add a small amount of water (about 1/2 cup). Cover tightly with more banana leaves and the pot lid. Steam for 30-40 minutes over medium heat until the matooke is very tender.
While the matooke is steaming, start the liver stew. In a saucepan, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Sauté the chopped onion until soft and translucent.
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger. Sauté for one minute until fragrant.
Add the chopped tomatoes and curry powder. Cook for 5-7 minutes, mashing the tomatoes until they form a thick paste.
Add the cleaned liver slices to the pot. Stir well to coat with the sauce. Cook for 5-7 minutes until the liver changes color on all sides.

Pour in one cup of water, add salt, and bring to a simmer. Reduce the heat, cover, and let it cook for 15-20 minutes, or until the liver is cooked through and tender. Add the green pepper in the last 5 minutes of cooking.

cooking_indicators.visual: sauce thickens, liver is brown and cooked through
cooking_indicators.texture: liver should be tender but not rubbery

steps.instruction: Mash the matooke: Once the steamed matooke is tender, transfer it to a separate bowl (or mash it directly in the pot). Use a wooden spoon or a masher to mash it until smooth and creamy. You can add a tablespoon of oil or a splash of hot water to achieve the desired consistency.
Serve the creamy mashed matooke hot, topped with a generous portion of the liver stew and its rich gravy.

serving_suggestions: Serve hot on its own or with a side of steamed vegetables like cabbage or dodo (amaranth).
